thread.title: The sit-ins that sparked social change
thread.title_full: The sit-ins that sparked social change

title: The sit-ins that sparked social change
text:
Sit-in movement sparks social change Updated 0120 GMT (0920 HKT) February 9, 2017 
Chat with us in Facebook Messenger. Find out what's happening in the world as it unfolds. Photos: Sit-in movement sparks social change Ronald Martin, Robert Patterson and Mark Martin sit at a whites-only lunch counter in Greensboro, North Carolina, on February 2, 1960. A day earlier, four African-American college students made history when they sat at the same Woolsworth's counter. Service never came for the "Greensboro Four," as they came to be known, and their peaceful demonstration drew national attention and sparked more sit-ins in Southern cities. Hide Caption Photos: Sit-in movement sparks social change People protest outside a Woolsworth's in Pittsburgh. Hide Caption 2 of 10 Photos: Sit-in movement sparks social change Dion Diamond is harassed during a sit-in at the Cherrydale Drug Fair in Arlington, Virginia. He was part of a small group called the Non-Violent Action Group. Some people threw lit cigarettes at group members, while others kicked them. The two-week protests in June 1960 led to the integration of restaurants in Arlington. Restaurants soon followed in nearby Alexandria and Fairfax. Hide Caption 3 of 10 Photos: Sit-in movement sparks social change Activists would often undergo tolerance training to prepare themselves for what they might encounter during a sit-in. Here, NAACP student adviser David Gunter, left, and Leroy Hill blow smoke into the face of Virginius Thornton. Hide Caption 4 of 10 Photos: Sit-in movement sparks social change Trainers in Petersburg, Virginia, use newspapers to swat volunteers in the head and prepare them for harassment they might encounter during a sit-in. Hide Caption Photos: Sit-in movement sparks social change Students wait in vain at a Greensboro Woolsworth's in April 1960. Hide Caption 6 of 10 Photos: Sit-in movement sparks social change Woolworth's temporarily closed a store in Atlanta after Harold Sprayberry sprayed insect repellant above the heads of nearly 100 sit-in protesters in October 1960. He was arrested, and the store reopened about an hour later. Hide Caption 7 of 10 Photos: Sit-in movement sparks social change People poured sugar, ketchup and mustard over the heads of Tougaloo College students who were conducting a sit-in at a Woolsworth's in Jackson, Mississippi, in May 1963. Sitting at the counter, from left, are Tougaloo professor John Salter and students Joan Trumpauer and Anne Moody. Hide Caption 8 of 10 Photos: Sit-in movement sparks social change A police officer in Birmingham, Alabama, frisks a demonstrator after an attempted sit-in on April 15, 1963. Hide Caption 9 of 10 Photos: Sit-in movement sparks social change Protesters fill a jail cell in Raleigh, North Carolina, in 1963. A year later, the Civil Rights Act outlawed discrimination in public places and facilities and banned discrimination based on race, gender, religion or national origin. Hide Caption 10 of 10 Four African-American college students made history when they sat down at a whites-only lunch counter in Greensboro, North Carolina, in February 1960. Service never came for the "Greensboro Four," as they came to be known, and their peaceful demonstration drew national attention and sparked more sit-ins in Southern cities. More from US
